results.title: KKND 2: Krush Kill 'N Destroy Krossfire for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM and CD jewel case with insert
results.brief_description: The battle for Earth rages on in the bleak world of KKnD2: Krossfire. The Survivors and Mutes from the previous game are joined by a new enemy: the Series 9. The Series 9 are a robot faction with origins in farm machinery. The radiation from mankind’s wars has warped their programming and they’ve taken up arms against the two original factions, who have destroyed the crops that they were designed to care for. As with the prior games, this game’s focus is resource management, base building, researching upgrades and the creation of units to defeat the other factions.

results.title: The Lion King: Simba's Mighty Adventure for Game Boy Color
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, plastic cartridge case, registration card, consumer information booklet and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Simba’s Mighty Adventure is based on Disney’s The Lion King as well as it’s direct-to-video sequel Simba’s Pride. The game consists of ten side-scrolling levels: The first six are set in The Lion King and the rest in Simba’s Pride, with some levels ending in boss fights. The game tracks along with the plot of both films and follows Simba as he grows up. Key events, such as the stampede from the first film, make up their own levels. Simba moves by running, jumping and climbing. Jumping can also be used to defeat the snakes, spiders, or monkeys that get in Simba’s way. He can also swipe at them with his claw or, as an adult, roar at them to make them flee.

Aiding Simba in his journey are collectibles that grant extra lives, refill or extend Simba’s health or fill a special amulet. Collecting all five parts of the amulet grants an extra life and opens up a mini-game that can be played main menu. The game also has a mulitplayer element. Using a Gameboy Colour link cable with another player opens up an extramode where each player has to hold onto a star for as long as possible by avoiding the opposing player’s attacks.

results.title: Stories from a flying trunk
results.creator_credit: Christine Edzard, Richard Goodwin, John Brabourne and EMI/Parlophone
results.brief_description: Entertaining children’s film combining the use of live action, animation and ballet to present adaptations of three Hans Christian Andersen fairytales - The Kitchen, The Little match girl and Little Ida - where nanimate kitchen objects come alive, vegetables stage a ballet and magic fills the air. Featuring members of the Royal Ballet, including Lesley Collier (Princess Ida), Graham Fletcher and Denise Nunn with choreography by Frederick Ashton, music by Rossini arranged by John Dalby and conducted by Philip Gammon. Cast also includes Murray Melvin, Ann Firbank, John Tordoff, John Dalby, Patricia Napier, Tasneem Maqsood (the match girl), Johanna Sonnex (Ida).

results.title: Stiletto [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Louise Leroux, Eric Michel and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: ‘Stiletto’ is an intriguing investigation of society’s fascination with fetishistic footwear. The impact of the stiletto heel on both fashion and culture is scrutinised from a number of perspectives by people including an historian, a podiatrist, a fashion therapist, a fashion designer, and the manufacturers of fetishistic shoes. Looks at stilettos in relation to roleplay, festishism, gender roles, foot- binding, and images of sexuality, using archival footage and photo- graphic stills as supporting evidence.

The impact of the stiletto heel on both fashion and culture is scrutinised from a number of perspectives by people including an historian, a podiatrist, a fashion therapist, a fashion designer, and the manufacturers of fetishistic shoes. Looks at stilettos in relation to roleplay, festishism, gender roles, foot- binding, and images of sexuality, using archival footage and photo- graphic stills as supporting evidence.

results.title: Warlords for Amiga
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. Two 3 1/2 inch floppy disks, colour map, product registration card, subscription card, Amiga Supplement sheet and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Warlords is set in the midst of the battle to control the Kingdom of Illuria. The player is put in control one of eight budding empires: The Sirians, Storm Giants, Grey Dwarves, Orcs of Kor, Elvallie, Horse Lords, Selentines, or Lord Bane. Each group has their strengths and weaknesses. The other clans are either controlled by the computer or by another player via hot seat play. The game proceeds on a turn-by-turn basis, with each player issuing commands such as to move units, attack the opposition, order cities to accrue gold, build more units or instruct their heroes to explore Illuria and complete quests before passing the turn to the next player. The game is won once a player has conquered at least half of the kingdom’s eighty cities.

results.title: Stigmata
results.creator_credit: Rupert Wainwright, Frank Mancuso and FGM Entertainment
results.brief_description: Bells toll over a mist-shrouded village in Brazil as top paranormal investigator for the Vatican, Father Andrew Kiernan (Gabriel Byrne), makes his way to the town’s church to determine the veracity of stories about a statue that had shed tears of blood since the death of the village priest, Father Almeida. While Father Kiernan struggles to present his case to high-ranking Vatican official Cardinal Houseman (Jonathon Pryce), in another town and another country, vivacious Pittsburgh hairdresser Frankie Paige (Patricia Arquette) is shown living a life of decadent abandon. A carefree spirit and atheist, she doesn’t have a care in the world until coming into contact with rosary beads stolen from Father Almeida. Suddenly, her life is turned upside down as she begins to experience violent, unexpected attacks that cause her to bleed profusely from her wrists. Trying to pick up the pieces of her life while plagued by further hallucinations and unexplained wounds, she comes under the scrutiny of the Vatican after a priest witnesses one of her attacks on a crowded train and suggests it may be religious in origin. Father Andrew Kiernan (Gabriel Byrne) is immediately dispatched to verify these claims. Initially he is sceptical, but after witnessing Frankie in the grip of possession, he begins to believe that she is suffering the stigmata, the wounds inflicted upon Christ prior to his crucifixion. When Cardinal Houseman discovers that Frankie is actually channeling a revolutionary message that may threaten the very foundations of the Catholic Church, he decides to silence her before any serious damage can be done. Father Kiernan is suddenly thrown into a desperate race against time to save both the precious message, and the life of the innocent messenger he has come to care deeply about, before both are extinguished forever. “Stigmata”, by acclaimed director of commercials and music videos, Rupert Wainwright, features stunning production design by Waldemar Kalinowski and a cutting edge soundtrack by Billy Corgan of the Smashing Pumpkins and Elia Cmiral. This video also includes the following special features: an alternative ending, the theatrical trailer, a short two-part documentary entitled Divine Rites: the story of Stigmata, the Natalie Imbruglia music video for the song - “Identify”, and scenes deleted from the final cut of the film.

results.title: Sticks and stones
results.creator_credit: Jan Padgett, George Johnson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Sticks and stones is an award-winning Canadian documentary aimed at promoting discussion of gay and gender-related issues between children, their teachers and parents. It uses the experiences, ideas and opinions of children themselves, some with gay parents, to examine non-traditional families, gender stereotyping and gender roles. Children are encouraged to find the reasons behind bullying and name-calling, and come up with their own solutions to these problems. Sticks and Stones is suitable for children aged 5 to 12; there is a related title In Other Words for older audiences.
